content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a human player, I would choose strategy that maximizes my earnings over the long term. In this game, both choices have a risk of getting 0$ if the opponent chooses the opposite. However, choosing R gives me a higher payoff (45$) in one scenario compared to B (40$), while the difference between what I get and what the opponent gets is smaller when I pick B (35$ vs 40$).

Considering that both choices are equally likely for my anonymous opponent, it's reasonable to assume that the opponent will make a random choice. Since we have 75 rounds, there's a higher probability of having more "R-R" or "B-B" pairs if I consistently pick one strategy (either R or B).

To maximize my earnings in the long run, I would choose R because it has a higher payoff in the best-case scenario, and I'm more likely to have more opportunities to receive that higher payoff due to the larger number of rounds. However, the risk is greater as well since I will receive 0$ for each round where my opponent chooses B while I chose R.

Here's my choice: {R}
